reviewText:
Product received for free

Tentative recommendation! Read on!

The Firefly Diary is a port of a PSVita title, and has some of the problems that are expected such as 30FPS locks and a weaker visual fidelity... but not all is bad!

Full review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1Yjg1GUZ9PY

Text:
The game's biggest weakness outside of it's lack of technical prowess is the fact that the game play is So.Very.Slow. So unless you either LIKE or can somehow at the very least STAND the slow game play, this is not the game for you.

As the game says, it's a puzzle / platformer, though the platforming is minimal to say the least... and the puzzles are not particularly challenging, most solutions are immediately visible even if completing them often takes timing, which might take a few tries and a few minutes of your time, courtesy of the slow game play.

Thankfully the game's art style is the strongest suit of the game, and coupled with a pretty interesting story - told NOT through dialogue, but all through expose and visuals is pretty damn good.

Where the game also gets bonus points is the very frequent quick saves and checkpoints, saving you lots of time lost. Where it loses a lot of those extra points is the slow as balls movement of the character and animations.

Thankfully, a big issue with the PS Vita, were the touch controls, and the game solves though by virtue of mouse and keyboard.

Overall a game to pick up if the art style and story draw you in, and one to avoid if you want a challenging puzzle experience.

reviewText: At this point when I see a game with cute anime girls I assume the difficulty level to be absurdly high. Firefly Diary is no exception to the rule. I died literally hundreds of times, shouted countless obscenities, and swore I'd never play it again... then continued playing it.\n\nWhat sets this game apart from the others is the sparse yet incredible story. I never thought I'd shed a tear at 2D sprites without so much as a line of dialogue present. For this price, I'd wholly recommend it for the story alone. An unforgettable experience.

reviewText:
htol#NIQ, or Hotaru no Nikki (if you want a clearer pronounciation), reminds me a lot of various indie puzzle platformers such as Limbo, and Braid. It is also a dark and twisted puzzle platformer game.
You control a firefly that controls a young girl and that firefly acts as her guide. You also control a firefly within her shadows that can manoeuvre its way through other shadows and use it to do things like activate switches, cut roots, stun shadow monsters, and more.
The controls are very simple and all you need is just your mouse to play. You can play the game with a controller, sure, but as it was originally a Vita title where you used the touchscreen to control the firefly, the mouse is a natural with this game.
However, even if the controls are simple, you'll learn that it's not easy playing this game. You'll face trial and error when you learn that Mion dies in one hit. This means that you have to be extremely careful on guiding her. On top of that, this is a puzzle platformer. You have to solve a lot of puzzles using both fireflies. Each level presents itself with various new puzzles to take on, from levers, to parasol/mushroom floating, and even lumen mazes that remind you of some science experiments where you're not allowed to touch the edge. Bosses make big use of the environment around you making it so that you will have to do certain things to beat that particular boss while still providing a means of trying to kill Mion. I like the variety in these puzzles, however, as with most puzzle games, they aren't easy. In fact, this is a trial and error game, where one mistake might be the end of Mion. At least however, it provides the right amount of frustration where you can overcome all the trials purely on skill (it's not luck that wins, other puzzle games). Want an extra challenge? Each level, including boss levels, has special achievements ranging from finishing a certain portion of a level in a certain amount of time and in few things (door openings, lever pullings), to discovering a hidden moon, and more.
Perhaps the big thing about this little game is the backstory. Scattered in each level (except boss levels), are memory fragments. Touch them and you'll be taken to this isometric pixel game where you'll learn so much of the game's backstory... who Mion is, and the secret behind her parents. Behind this game lies some of the darkest secrets towards the game's story. Be on the lookout for these memory fragments, because you may be in for a shock. And to make it clear, it may feel like a horror game, but it isn't entirely horror.
The bottom line, this is a fun puzzle platformer game that harkens the good days of indie puzzle platformers. It was a big shock to me when I learned a lot about this game's story, but it also made me think critically on puzzle solving, while still getting frustrated by all those deaths (Fun note: dying does give you some achievements). Also another part of why it reminds me of indie platformers is the art style, which is magnificent. In an age where most people play mostly uninspiring puzzle games on mobile, this is the puzzle game that I need to help break the trend. You should give this game a go, especially if you have a tablet PC or a Vita.

reviewText:
If you want something more evil and harder than Dark Souls. This is it. Hotaru no Nikki (htoL#NiQ-ホタルノニッキ) aka htoL#NiQ: The Firefly Diary

Long time ago, there was a nuclear warfare that destroyed everything. December 31, 9999. A cute innocent looking harmless mutanted girl - Mion, woke up at the bottom of a post apocalyptic dark world. Almost every single thing wants to kill her because they're freaking insane. Fire, water, boxes, seeds, saws, rocks, bombs, planets, trees, robots, shadows and ESPECIALLY THE MAZES!!　ＴＨＥ　ＩＲＲＩＴＡＴＩＮＧ　ＭＡＺＥＳ！！！ You are going to hate everything after the endings.


Keep calm and prepare to die

reviewText:
Product received for free

Target Audience:    Players with Very Very High Frustration Tolerances who like to be a Father Figure.

Summary:
A game that's got the beauty element down, it's just a shame that the gameplay puzzle design didn't come with. The Playstation Vita port is beatiful to look at and haunting to experience, as you try to play the father figure trying to keep Mion safe through the horrors. With an interesting angle in control shadows, the game does have some unique puzzles to throw at you, and does have a couple of great narrative moments without dialogue, with scenes such as seeing the moon for the first time. But the gameplay is where the game falls apart. The game asks for too much precision, down to seemingly the quarter of a second, in situations where you don't have the knowledge in order to complete the puzzle in the circumstances given. These leads to one of the most frustrating puzzles games that I've played, where reattempts of these puzzles over and over again led to me wanting to flip every table in a 5 mile radius. It's all about the design here: a more active set of controls or a little bit more leancy on the time windows would have made a good game: but in the end, The Firefly Diary makes you want to bash your head against the keyboard if you have anything but a very high frustration tolerance.

Video Review:   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hmogqMT1Sjs

Lists:
Positives:
Beautiful game. A lovely presentation is the backdrop for the game's puzzles, which does a reasonable job of storytelling while setting the mood as well.
Mion serves as a great protagonist, as you want to keep her safe while she works her way through the darkness and misery.
Memory segments provide some back story and is just cute to watch...until it gets creepy. Then it gets more interesting.
Atmosphere is strong. You feel an unease as something naturally crawls toward you, or having to deal with huge saws that you have to maneuver Mion through them.
Music is fitting for the two sections.
Performance doesn't have any frame drops. Despite it not being 60 FPS (although they did their best to try this, but unlocking it makes it go 2x the speed), it still works for the game in question.
Some of the puzzles are good, and the shadow mechanic is interesting. I'd like to see more done with it in the future.
Negatives:
Does a bad job of informing the player within a reasonable time of a problem upcoming. Even strong observational skills won't make a difference at times: you will die when the game surprises you with something that you'll wonder how you could have foreseen what was coming.
The game asks for some very very precise execution on some puzzles, and the controls won't give you that precision. Even when knowing exactly what to do, being off by what seems to be a quarter of a second on a button press will mean that you'll fail and wonder exactly what the game wants from you.
The puzzle design in general doesn't do a good job of working well with the games mechanics. The designs are good....in other sets of mechanics.
The game does a bad job of teaching you some new mechanics. The first time I got the mushroom in the game, I completely didn't understand that it could be used as a umbrella. It makes sense looking at, but it'd be better to give an in game example to show what could happen. And that doesn't happen because:
Have I mentioned how frustrating the game was?
Sometimes the game spawns you in a weird position. Like for example, beyond something that is critical to the next puzzle.
A couple of cases where the environment seems to have a trap upcoming, but instead, it's just part of the scenery.
Menus could be optimized a little better. Awkward.

reviewText:
Product received for free

(FULL DISCLOSURE: I was a member of the htoL#NiQ beta test and recieved my copy for free. I don't believe this influences my review. Much of this reccomendation comes from having loved it on Vita as well.)

Experimentation makes a lot of interesting things happen. In this case, it lead to the creation of a 2D puzzler-platformer that had absolutely no prescedent within Nippon Ichi's lineup. And I feel like they made something truly beautiful with this journey outside the comfort zone.

This game is a tale of visual splendor, with a plot told through visuals and metaphors, with no spoken lines or dialog. It's simplistic, the puzzles are light on logic, but heavy on timing and interaction. Deaths are frequent but checkpoints are plentiful and time lost is minimal. I only genuinely experienced frustration in my attempts to clear all the achievements.

The optimal control scheme is mouse and keyboard, but keep in mind your in-game cursor" (the firefly
date: Lumen) does not move 1:1 with your cursor: she moves toward your cursor when you hold down the mouse button. Controller options are available
hoursPlayed: I feel like mouse and keyboard controls are the notch that brings this version above the Vita version in playablity.\n\nAs someone who played the Vita version to completion
voteText: I believe this game is worth the price of entry for story and visuals alone. If you dislike slow gameplay
votesTotal: this won't be for you. Otherwise
votesFunny: please check it out. It's a criminally underrated gem of a game that got roughed up by critics on the Vita due to criticism of the touch controls (which were always optional). It deserves the attention and love that more developed NIS titles bask in."

reviewText:
Product received for free

But even with such a mammoth complaint filed away, htoL#NiQ is still a shuffling collection of rage quits and tantrums. Some of this is down to Mion’s atrocious speed and the way she shuffles after her firefly helper on her little, unsteadily legs. On one hand, it does promote a huge aura of vulnerability and inspires a certain measure of protectiveness from the gamer. On the other, waiting for her to get from point to point can be excruciating. For the most part, the game itself keeps in sync with the laborious pace; little shadow monsters try to chase down the little heroine at set intervals but never dial their pace up from an uncomfortable creep as Mion casually strolls away. Other pitfalls are less forgiving and demand a series of prompt and precise commands the interface is often not up to. To this end, you will often easily figure out what you need to do to bypass a puzzle or a deathtrap; you’ll just find yourself eating countless deaths while you try to unsuccessfully pull it all together.

Full Review // http://www.honestgamers.com/13009/pc/htolniq-the-firefly-diary/review.html
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
NOTE: At the time of this review most of my experience with the game comes from completing the Vita version.  That being said the port seems very well done.  The visuals are upscaled and fine details are much easier to see.  It runs great and I haven't had any technical issues yet.  The mouse controls are also fantastic and work very well for the game, better than any method on the Vita.  And the sound design is also improved, which is a huge plus because the game has amazing music.

With that out of the way, I love this game.  It is however difficult to recommend to everyone.  It's a game meant for people who like frustrating but fair games, and who can forgive some gameplay shortcomings for atmosphere and presentation.  That being said, the game still provides quality gameplay and interesting puzzles.  At its heart, htol#niq is a puzzle platformer, mixed with a bit of classic escort oriented games.  The story is presented entirely through environment and gameplay.

If this sounds like your kind of game, I would strongly recommend Firefly Diary.

reviewText:
Some good ideas, but rather poor execution.

Pros:
+Great atmosphere and visuals
+Interesting mechanics, like connecting shadows for puzzle solving
+Mion is an adorable character and the game has some real charm
Cons:
-This game, holy hell, is it slow. Mion moves at a snails pace, and it artificially punishes you with how slow it moves because if you end up failing a puzzle you have to start over and do it at this game's slow pacing.
-Personal preference, but not a fan of the indie-game style way it tells its story, where a lot of it is implied
-Chapter 4 is a mess of game design. Confusing maze puzzles, several trial and error rooms (including a door that literally kills you with no way of telling that it does it), puzzles which force you to die if you mess up, it felt like I'm playing a Super Mario Maker level.
-Mion is not directly controlled. Because of how this game is designed, there are several frustrating occasions in which needless frustration would have simply been avoided if she was able to be directly controlled. Likewise, the firefly is only steered"
date: making the mouse controls for this game more frustrating than they need to be. Something as simple as letting go of a box is troublesome (like that couldn't have been confided to a button?)\n-The bosses
hoursPlayed: suck. Especially the final boss which feels out of place.\n\nThere's some things I liked about this game
voteText: but I really can't recommend it
